awd_titl_txt: RUI: WoU-MMA: Analysis of TeV Gamma-rays from Active Galaxies and Dark Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
Gamma rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation. Observations of astrophysical gamma rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe and can be used to test fundamental physics. The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), located in southern Arizona, is a ground-based observatory designed to study high-energy gamma rays. VERITAS has unique capabilities, providing high sensitivity pointed observations of both galactic and extragalactic sources. This award supports scientists at California Polytechnic State University to carry out research with VERITAS and with the new co-located prototype Schwartzchild-Couder Telescope (pSCT).  The group will work on extensions to the gamma-ray detection algorithms for VERITAS and the pSCT to further improve the sensitivity of the telescopes.  Undergraduate students will be involved in the research.  The group will also work with the Physics Teachers of the Central Coast through the Center for Engineering, Science and Education at California Polytechnic State University to develop educational modules around morphology, spectra, and variability of active galaxies. 

VERITAS has embarked upon a broad program of Galactic and extragalactic source observations, as well as searches for very-high-energy electromagnetic counterparts to sources of gravitational waves and neutrinos.  With this award the California Polytech State University group will work on extensions to the Image Template Method (ITM), a new gamma-ray reconstruction algorithm.  With the improved sensitivity enabled by ITM the group will search for very-high-energy gamma rays from active galaxies, which are likely to be the sites of multi-messenger acceleration, and use observations of dwarf galaxies to set dark matter limits.  The group will engage undergraduate students in the discovery of new very-high-energy emitting active galaxies triggered by the VERITAS Target of Opportunity program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goals of this project were to improve VERITAS gamma-ray detection algorithms and to use the improved algorithms to study the acceleration mechanisms of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) while bringing astrophysics experiences to Cal Poly undergraduate students. AGN are classified as Blazars when the jet of high-energy particles is oriented toward our telescopes on earth. Slightly misaligned jets are classified as Radio Galaxies. The key to understanding the physical mechanisms close to the black hole is to measure the high-energy spectrum of these sources. We have worked with the broader astrophysics community on multi-wavelength spectra and also multi-messenger detection of AGN. 

The VERITAS collaboration has detected more than 64 very-high energy (VHE) gamma-ray sources with the Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array (VERITAS), located at the Whipple Observatory in Southern Arizona. Of note in the list of detections is 3C 264 which was the second radio galaxy discovered by VERITAS. The new Shower-Image Template Stereo-Reconstruction Method (ITM) developed by the PI using support from a previous grant was instrumental for extracting this science. During this grant cycle, the ITM algorithm has been used by the Cal Poly Undergraduates to increase the sensitivity of six VERITAS blazar discovery targets.  Our collaborators at U. Minnesota also used it in the discovery of very-high energy gamma-ray emissions of RBS 1366. The surprisingly hard spectrum of RBS 1366 has prompted its reclassification as an Extreme high-synchrotron-peak blazars (EHBL). Finally, we are also using the ITM algorithm at Cal Poly to analyze two flares of the blazar 1ES 2344+514, one from December 17 to 18, 2015 and another from November 28 to December 3, 2021.  This EHBL flares somewhat frequently for a few-days at a time. Our observations are interesting because the enhanced flux is primarily in the VERITAS energy band. There is no strong evidence for a simultaneous increase in flux at the lower energies observed by the Fermi-LAT.  In addition to the science, the PI provides leadership for the VEGAS code including maintenance, new algorithm projects, development of calibration constants, and the corresponding instrument response functions for the VERITAS instrument. 

The broader impacts of this work include the educational development of undergraduates and community outreach.  In 2017, the PI invited undergraduates to join the VERITAS effort to discover very-high-energy gamma-ray emission from Active Galaxies.  Since then, twenty students have participated in the project.  They have learned new computer skills and the data analysis techniques needed to identify gamma-ray signals.  They related the signals to the physical mechanisms going on near the supermassive black holes in AGN.  The extreme application of modern physics combined with the excitement of discovering new sources of very-high energy gamma rays is a powerful introduction to what research is all about and it is a great motivator for studying physics.  The computational nature of this work also served students well during the Covid shutdowns when face-to-face research wasn’t possible.  In the past two years, six students were able to join the PI on 5-day observing shifts in Arizona.  Many of the students are pursuing graduate studies.  The PI also served on the VERITAS Science Board as the representative for the Associate Members.
